description.plain:
Aerosmith is an American rock band, sometimes referred to as “The Bad Boys from Boston” and “America’s Greatest Rock and Roll Band.” Formed in 1970, its founding members are Steven Tyler (vocals, keyboards, harmonica), Tom Hamilton (bass), Joey Kramer (drums), Joe Perry (guitar, vocals) and Brad Whitford (guitar).

The band released their eponymous debut studio album in 1973 featuring the single “Dream On,” which remains one of their most popular songs. Their next four albums made them rock stars across the US and Canada, spawning the hits “Sweet Emotion”, “Last Child”, “Walk This Way”, “Back In The Saddle”, “Draw The Line”, and a cover of “Come Together” for the Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band Soundtrack.

Before the release of their fifth album Draw The Line, the band’s substance abuse began to destroy them. Perry quit after a backstage fight with Tyler in 1979, and Whitfield left two years later. Despite moderate sales, the band’s fifth, sixth and seventh albums were considered flops when compared to the band’s past accomplishments. When Perry and Whitfield returned in 1984, their eighth album Done With Mirrors was also deemed unsuccessful despite strong reviews. Doug Herzog (MTV, VH1) recalled:

Aerosmith was done at that point. Their last couple of records had been huge bombs. They had fallen into major drug problems. They were a little bit of a joke.

In 1986, Tyler & Perry were recruited for a collaboration with rap group Run DMC for a groundbreaking hip-hop-meets-rock reworking of “Walk This Way” – an idea of Run DMC’s label head/producer Rick Rubin. The song was a surprise international smash hit, reaching the top 10 in eight countries. This, combined with the band going clean & sober, and allowing help from outside songwriters, led to what’s been called ‘one of the most impressive career comebacks in rock history’ with their ninth album Permanent Vacation. The album spawned three top 20 US hits that also had a moderate impact overseas.

Aerosmith’s next three albums Pump, Get A Grip and Nine Lives would rack up nine more top 40 US hits. And their 1998 Diane Warren-penned chart-topper “I Don’t Want To Miss A Thing” for the film Armageddon would propel the band even further into worldwide stardom, reaching the top 5 in eight countries.

The band has sold over 150 million albums, won four Grammys and was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall Of Fame. Aerosmith’s albums in the 2000s have all reached the top 5 in the US, with their thirteenth Just Push Play giving the band its last US top 10 hit “Jaded” in 2001.

songs.full_title: I Don't Want to Miss a Thing by Aerosmith
songs.title: I Don’t Want to Miss a Thing
songs.title_with_featured: I Don't Want to Miss a Thing

description.plain:
“I Don’t Want to Miss a Thing” was Aerosmith’s first number one song. It was featured in the movie Armageddon, which starred Steven Tyler’s daughter, Liv Tyler. U2 was originally asked to perform this song for the movie—the idea for Aerosmith performing it only came after Liv was cast.

Aerosmith’s guitarist Joe Perry explained to Classic Rock magazine in 2002:

At the time, we just didn’t have the time to settle down and do it. We were out on the road, so they brought us in to see the movie and said ‘here’s the song, this is where it fits into the movie, you can do it if you want.’ So we were in the studio within the next three days cutting it. And yeah, we do wish that we’d had a little more time, so that we could have had a shot at writing it, but it was perfect timing. The song was great, people loved it, and I don’t think people care that much who wrote it.

Spinner claims that songwriter Diane Warren intended the song to be for Celine Dion.

songs.full_title: Dream On by Aerosmith
songs.title: Dream On

description.plain:
Off of their first LP, this is one of Aerosmith’s biggest early hits, along with “Walk This Way” and “Sweet Emotion.”

Frontman Steven Tyler began writing the song on his father’s Estey upright organ as teen and finished it on a piano in the basement where the band lived in the early 1970s. He claims the ‘chordage’ of the song came from laying under his father’s piano as a child and listening to him play.

On its original 1973 release, “Dream On” charted at #59 (though regionally in New England it was more successful).  But after the top 40 success of “Sweet Emotion” from their 3rd album in 1975, the re-release of “Dream On” sent the song all the way to #6 the following year. It remained their biggest hit until “Angel” reached #3 twelve years later.

“Dream On” is a bittersweet take on aging, and how one should continue to live one’s life to the fullest as time is a commodity that we don’t have control over and the “good Lord” is able to take us away at any time.

songs.full_title: Cryin' by Aerosmith
songs.title: Cryin’

description.plain:
“Cryin” is a song by Aerosmith, the American rock band. It was released as their second single in 1993, from the Geffen produced album Get A Grip. It became the band’s second Top 40 hit from the album, peaking at the No. 12 position on the Billboard Hot 100 and topping its Mainstream Album Rock chart.

The music video features Alicia Silverstone, who plays a rebellious ex girlfriend. Out of the frustration caused by her ex, she gets a navel piercing (and goes bungee-jumping with the rope attached to it). This is now credited as the reason for the certain piercing’s sudden popularity.



The video, directed by Marty Callner, features the first of three appearances by Alicia Silverstone in the band’s videos, the next two being “Amazing” (1993) and “Crazy” (1994) also directed by Callner.

songs.full_title: Walk This Way by Aerosmith
songs.title: Walk This Way

description.plain:
“Walk This Way” is one of Aerosmith’s signature songs. It was released in 1975 as the second single from the album Toys in the Attic. It did not originally chart, but after “Dream On” from the band’s debut album was reissued and climbed to #6 in 1976, “Walk This Way” was also reissued and reached #10 in early 1977.

The band got the idea for the song’s lyrics from a line in the film Young Frankenstein that originally came from The Three Stooges. While the lyrics sound dirty on the surface, the less obvious meaning trumps it. The title of the song derives from the idea that his fingers are moving in a walking motion while he is sexually pleasing her.

In 1986, producer Rick Rubin arranged for Run DMC to do a cover of the song involving both Tyler and Perry. While both acts were initially hesitant and uninterested, the song became a surprise top 10 hit in the US and the UK, and revived Aerosmith’s career which, at the time, was a low point.

While the lyrics sound dirty on the surface, the less obvious meaning trumps it. The title of the song derives from the idea that his fingers are moving in a walking motion while he is sexually pleasing her.

In 1986, producer Rick Rubin arranged for Run DMC to do a cover of the song involving both Tyler and Perry. While both acts were initially hesitant and uninterested, the song became a surprise top 10 hit in the US and the UK, and revived Aerosmith’s career which, at the time, was a low point.

songs.full_title: Sweet Emotion by Aerosmith
songs.title: Sweet Emotion

description.plain:
Sweet Emotion was released in April 1975 by Columbia Records on Toys in the Attic, Aerosmith’s third album. The single version was released for radio play on May 19th, 1975. Sweet Emotion was also Aerosmith’s first Top 40 single, reaching No. 36 on July 19th, 1975.

Steven Tyler was inspired to write the lyrics about his anger & jealousy when Joe Perry moved out of the apartment the band shared to live with his then-girlfriend Alyssa.

songs.full_title: Dude (Looks Like a Lady) by Aerosmith
songs.title: Dude (Looks Like a Lady)

description.plain:
“Dude (Looks Like a Lady)” is a song by American hard rock band Aerosmith, featured on their ninth studio album, Permanent Vacation, and was released as the lead single, reaching #4 on the US Rock Chart in September 1987.

It was the first of three singles from the album that broke the top 20 in the US, peaking at #14 on December 12, 1987. It was also a moderate hit in the UK, reaching #45.

According to a September 2013 Huffington Post article, it was written about a time the band walked into a bar and mistook Mötley Crüe lead singer Vince Neil for a female. When the band presented it to Desmond Child, a songwriter who had been asked to assist the band, the piece was titled “Cruisin' For The Ladies.” Child encouraged frontman Steven Tyler to go back to using his original lyric—“That dude looks like a lady”—and to write about “the whole scenario of a guy that walks into a strip joint and falls in love with the stripper on stage, goes backstage and finds out it’s a guy.”

songs.full_title: Janie's Got a Gun by Aerosmith
songs.title: Janie’s Got a Gun

description.plain: “Janie’s Got A Gun” is a song from the 1990 Aerosmith album Pump. After thinking about the title, Steven Tyler wrote lyrics inspired by two different stories he read in Time and Newsweek: one involving gun violence within the US towards the end of the 1980s and the other involving sexual abuse of children in well off suburban communities.  The latter story (a young teenager being sexually abused by her father) became a motive for the former (Janie killing someone, in this case her father).

songs.full_title: Jaded by Aerosmith
songs.title: Jaded

description.plain:
“Jaded” is a song by American hard rock band Aerosmith. It was written by Steven Tyler and Marti Frederiksen. The single was released on December 21, 2000 as the first single from the album Just Push Play. The song was debuted publicly at the American Music Awards and was also played at the halftime show for Super Bowl XXXV in January 2001. It was ranked No. 86 on VH1’s 100 Greatest Songs of the ‘00s.

“Jaded” became Aerosmith’s final chart hit in most territories. It reached number one on both the US Billboard Mainstream Rock chart and the UK Rock Chart, while reaching the top 10 on the Billboard Hot 100 and in Canada and Scotland. On the UK Singles Chart, the song reached number 13 and became the band’s eighth top-twenty single on that chart. It also reached number 11 in Italy, number 17 in the Netherlands, number 18 in Spain, and charted well in several other European countries and New Zealand.

songs.full_title: Angel by Aerosmith
songs.title: Angel

description.plain:
Aerosmith scored their first top 20 single in over ten years with “Dude (Looks Like a Lady)”, the first single from Permanent Vacation. But its third single, “Angel”, outdid all of their previous hits.

After reaching #4 on the US Rock Chart in March 1988, “Angel” also crossed over to pop – climbing all the way to #3 that April, one spot higher than their 1986 collaboration with Run-DMC “Walk This Way”. “Angel” also performed well in Canada and was a minor UK hit.

“Angel” remains their second-biggest hit to date behind the Diane Warren-penned chart-topper “I Don’t Want To Miss A Thing” ten years later.

Guitarist Joe Perry once shared that some accused the band of selling out with this monster ballad, but would come back with “What about ‘Dream On’?”

songs.full_title: Livin' on the Edge by Aerosmith
songs.title: Livin’ on the Edge

description.plain:
“Livin on the Edge” is a slow, trippy rock song that plays similarly to a ballad, but with lyrics focusing more on lifestyle and mortality than love, romance and other subject matters to which ballads are normally attached. It was Aerosmith’s first single from Get a Grip, and was one of four Top 40 hits from the album.

The meaning behind this song isn’t very apparent from the lyrics.  By reading the lyrics while watching the video, you can see what the lyricist meant by the “edge”.  The edge can be interpreted in a few ways.  Living on the edge could be taken as living a risky lifestyle (as when the kid crashed his car into the blinking road construction sign and throwing away the condom that the Dad gives the kid) or living on the edge of gender (constant references to crossdressing and feminization of males and masculinization of females).  It seems that Aerosmith is commenting on the reversal of the natural state of our society by the elites.  The lyric, “something’s wrong in the world today and God knows it ain’t his”, speaks to the fact that Aerosmith is referencing a patriarchal social structure as the norm.  The video is heavily influenced by Fraternal Imagery and phallic symbols.  This fraternal influence is hidden from the general public, that think the natural evolution of society is toward more gender bending and androgyny, but this trend is actually being forced on us by the power elites to make us more easily controllable.

songs.full_title: Rag Doll by Aerosmith
songs.title: Rag Doll

description.plain:
“Rag Doll” was the second single from Permanent Vacation, originally only issued as a promotional release to radio. The song reached #12 on the US Rock Chart in November 1987. But after the top 3 pop success of “Angel”, “Rag Doll” was officially released as the third commercial single and became the album’s third top 20 US hit, peaking at #17 in August 1988. “Rag Doll” also found success in Canada, Ireland, The Netherlands and the UK.

Its title was originally “Ragtime” (it has a bit of rag time vibe to it) and had a different chorus, but co-writer Holly Knight suggested changing it to “Rag Doll” because she felt ‘ragtime’ was “not very edgy or sexy, or ‘anything’ really”.

songs.full_title: Last Child by Aerosmith
songs.title: Last Child

description.plain:
“Last Child” is one of few Aerosmith tracks to be written in part by rhythm guitarist Brad Whitford. There is some debate over who actually played the guitar solo on the record (most believe it to be Joe Perry), but Brad Whitford always plays it during live performances.

When discussing his love for Rocks, which he cites as the album that made him want to learn to play guitar, Slash talks in particular about the great one-two punch of the first two songs on the album: “Back in the Saddle” and “Last Child.”

songs.full_title: Big Ten Inch Record by Aerosmith
songs.title: Big Ten Inch Record

description.plain:
“Big Ten-Inch Record” is a cover of ‘dirty blues’ sax man Bull Moose Jackson’s 1952 song. It was written as a double entendre about ten-inch vinyl records that were common in the early 1900s.



A friend of the band (actually, their drug dealer) introduced them to this song after hearing the original track on Dr Demento’s syndicated radio show.

songs.full_title: Falling in Love (Is Hard on the Knees) by Aerosmith
songs.title: Falling in Love (Is Hard on the Knees)
songs.title_with_featured: Falling in Love (Is Hard on the Knees)

description.plain: Steven Tyler reflects on all the pain one goes through while falling in love. Co-written by Glen Ballard, the original producer of Nine Lives before he was ditched and replaced with Kevin Shirley, “Falling In Love” continued Aerosmith’s winning streak  in the 90s, topping Billboard’s Mainstream Rock Tracks and reaching #35 on the Hot 100. The surreal Michael Bay-directed music video, described as “12 Monkeys meets Brazil” and a parody of grunge videos (“Real angry, heavy, evil, with people beating things”), won the MTV Video Music Award for Best Rock Video.

songs.full_title: Eat the Rich by Aerosmith
songs.title: Eat the Rich

description.plain: “Eat The Rich” was the second single from Get a Grip. While it did do well on rock stations, reaching #5 on the US Rock Chart, it did not cross over to pop like the album’s lead single “Livin' On The Edge” and its later singles “Cryin'”, “Amazing” and “Crazy” – which all made the top 40 on the Hot 100. It was a modest hit on the pop charts in Canada and Australia, however. The song was written in co-writer Jim Vallance’s basement studio.

songs.full_title: Back in the Saddle by Aerosmith
songs.title: Back in the Saddle

description.plain:
When the band was recording their album Rocks in 1975, producer Jack Douglas talked with songwriter Steven Tyler about using the phrase “back in the saddle” as a way of saying the band was back with a hard-rocking new album.

Tyler had always thought of the phrase not as “making a comeback”, but “having sex more than once a night”, and therefore wrote a song about a cowboy’s sexual escapades.

songs.full_title: Toys in the Attic by Aerosmith
songs.title: Toys in the Attic

description.plain:
The opening title track to Aerosmith’s 1975 album of the same name, and the B-side of the third single from the album, You See Me Crying. Written by vocalist Steven Tyler and lead guitarist Joe Perry, “Toys In The Attic” is rather vague in its actual song meaning, for it’s been theorized to be about anything from actual toys in the attic to a figure of speech meaning “going crazy,” and thus being about someone going mad due to drugs or some other substance. It’s one of the fastest and hardest songs in the album, which in turn makes it a great song to open the album with.

Its influence was far-reaching according to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame: they ranked it on their list of the Top 500 songs that shaped Rock and Roll.

songs.full_title: The Other Side by Aerosmith
songs.title: The Other Side

description.plain: Aerosmith’s fifth single from Pump, “The Other Side” became their third No. 1 Mainstream Rock hit from the album and their fourth song from the album to reach the Top 40 of the Billboard Hot 100 (it reached No. 22). Interestingly Holland-Dozier-Holland sued Aerosmith due to the main hook’s similarities with The Four Tops song “Standing in the Shadows of Love.” Holland-Dozier-Holland won the suit and so they now receive partial songwriting credit alongside Steven Tyler and Jim Vallance.

songs.full_title: F.I.N.E. by Aerosmith
songs.title: F.I.N.E.

description.plain:
The second track off of Aerosmith’s eighth studio album, Pump (which was sandwiched between Permanent Vacation and Get a Grip in a series of comeback records produced by Bruce Fairbairn), “F.I.N.E” brings Aerosmith back to their heavy rock roots.



In the album’s liner notes, it shows that the song’s title is merely an acronym, standing for “Fucked Up, Insecure, Neurotic and Emotional.” The song’s lyrics encompass these adjectives via various situations portrayed in the song.

songs.full_title: Uncle Salty by Aerosmith
songs.title: Uncle Salty

description.plain:
The second track on Aerosmith’s 1975 album Toys in the Attic. Written by vocalist Steven Tyler and bassist Tom Hamilton, “Uncle Salty” tells the story of a woman who leads a lonely life of child abuse and eventually prostitution.

The theme of child abuse would eventually be revisited in Janie’s Got a Gun, except in a more condemning nature than this song.

description.plain: One of Aerosmith’s most unique covers, “Remember (Walking in the Sand)” was originally recorded by ‘60s girl group The Shangri-Las and was so beloved it was included in Rolling Stone’s list of the Top 500 Songs of All Time. A little-known fact about the Aerosmith version of the song is that Mary Weiss, the lead singer of the Shangri-Las, came to the studio to sing backup on it.

songs.full_title: Deuces Are Wild by Aerosmith
songs.title: Deuces Are Wild

description.plain:
This sunny ballad was originally recorded by songwriter Jim Vallance in 1988 during the sessions for Pump with Steven Tyler adding his vocals, but it was nixed by Geffen A&R representative John Kalodner who didn’t like the title “Deuces are Wild.”

Five years later, the original demo Vallance recorded, with Tyler’s vocals and “some additional guitar and drums” was included on the compilation The Beavis And Butthead Experience, then featured on the Big Ones greatest hits compilation the following year.

“Deuces Are Wild” became the groups' sixth song to top the Billboard Mainstream Rock chart, holding that position for four weeks. Since then, it has been included in virtually every Aerosmith greatest hits collection and has become a live staple for the band.

songs.full_title: You See Me Crying by Aerosmith
songs.title: You See Me Crying

description.plain:
By far Aerosmith’s most complex song up to this point in their careers, “You See Me Crying” ended up frustrating several members of Aerosmith during the recording process due to how long it took to finish it. Producer Jack Douglas brought in an orchestra directed by Mike Mainieri which led to the length of time it took to record it. Even so, the label was so impressed that they released the song as the album’s third and final single with “Toys In The Attic” as the B-Side. Steven Tyler liked it, too, even though he later forgot that he had written it. During the recording of Done with Mirrors in 1984, Steven (who was plagued with memory issues due to his heavy drug use) heard it on the radio and told Joe Perry that Aerosmith should do a cover. Joe Perry simply replied “It’s us, Fuckhead.”

It’s interesting to note that Perry actually plays rhythm guitar on this song, swapping places with Brad Whitford who played lead.

songs.full_title: Nobody's Fault by Aerosmith
songs.title: Nobody’s Fault

description.plain:
“Nobody’s Fault” has never been the most popular Aerosmith song, but its quality has been noted by many including Steven Tyler himself who has called it one of the highlights of his career. Guns N' Roses guitarist Slash, who has stated that it was Rocks that inspired him to become a guitarist, lists “Nobody’s Fault” as his favorite Aerosmith song of all time.

Amusingly in the song’s quiet intro, you can hear a door open. Steven Tyler has noted that it was somebody coming into the studio to hear the band’s recording process and that he and Joe Perry looked at each other and grimaced when the door creaked open, but that take ended up being the best one and so the door remains as a creaky easter egg on the LP.

description.plain:
Tyler said that its original title was actually “Tits on a Crib” because of a girl he was seeing at the time. She had a baby, and when Steven invited her over, she would bring the kid on a crib because she couldn’t get a baby sitter.
The harmonica section of the song was inspired by Midnight Rambler by the Rolling Stones.

songs.full_title: Hangman Jury by Aerosmith
songs.title: Hangman Jury

description.plain:
Though not released in physical format, “Hangman Jury” became the third song from Aerosmith’s big comeback album Permanent Vacation to chart on the US Rock Chart. The song spent 12 weeks on the it, peaking at #14 in December 1987.

In it, Tyler tells the story of a man who shoots his complaining wife while drunk, and ends up on death row. This swampy blues number borrows heavily from an old folk song named “Linin' Track”, eventually recorded by Leadbelly in 1962. Though the song actually pre-dates Leadbelly’s recording of it, he claimed ownership of it. Tyler thought the song was in the public domain, and therefore free to take from, but he was mistaken. So some writing credits (and royalties) go to the owner of Leadbelly’s music.

description.plain: “Sick as a Dog” features a coda section where the rest of the band besides Joe Perry drops out before coming back in all together. This was done mechanically as well as musically as the song was recorded in one take and when the coda begins, bassist Tom Hamilton hands his bass off to Steven Tyler and plays rhythm guitar for the rest of the song.

songs.full_title: Walkin' the Dog by Aerosmith
songs.title: Walkin’ the Dog

description.plain:
“Walkin' the Dog” is a cover of the hit song  written and originally performed by acclaimed African-American rhythm and blues artist Rufus Thomas, Jr. “Walkin' the Dog” was released as a track on his 1963 album by the same name and was certified gold.  Countless versions of the song exist; it has been covered by The Rolling Stones (1964), The Kingsmen (1965), [Ratt (1983), and Green Day (1993), among others.

The verses refer to two children’s rhymes, “Mary Mack” and “Mary Mary Quite Contrary.” However, the meaning of the term repeated in the chorus, “Walkin' the dog,” is open to interpretation.  “Walk the dog” is a yoyo trick, a slang term for having sex, and a slang term for masturbation.

Thomas could also have been referencing “The Dog,” a dance from the 1960s; or the 1916 fox trot “Walkin' the Dog”.   You can check out an instrumental version of the 1916 track here.

songs.title: Rats in the Cellar

description.plain:
Promo single for the album “Rocks”, was released in May 3, 1976.

Steven Tyler said in his book “Does The Noise in My Head Bother You?” that he wrote this song as a salutation/ answer to “Toys In The Attic”. But, according to him, “Rats” was more according to what was happening at the time. Things were falling apart, chaotic, they were careless and sanity was fading away.

The song is mostly a rock and roll song, it starts off with a drum line and goes into slow blues jam with Steven singing about a letter from a lover he is waiting for. songs.full_title: Taste of India by Aerosmith
songs.title: Taste of India

description.plain:
This dark, heavy Rocker is notable for its use of native Indian instruments including a sarangi intro from Ramesh Mishra. It was a major hit for Aerosmith, peaking at No 3 on Billboard’s Mainstream Rock chart and was played heavily throughout Aerosmith’s Nine Lives tour from 1997 to 1999. In her review of the album, Rolling Stone writer Elysa Gardner compared the song to Led Zeppelin’s Kashmir.

Steven Tyler got the idea for the song when he saw a restaurant with the same name.

description.plain: The song serves as a short introduction to Aerosmith’s 1993 album Get a Grip. It contains rapped vocals in a similar style to their hit “Walk This Way”, which featured Run D.M.C. That song was a remix of a song from Aerosmith’s 1975 album Toys in the Attic, and contains an interpolation of its riff. The song segues into the following song, titled “Eat the Rich”.

songs.full_title: Let the Music Do the Talking by Aerosmith
songs.title: Let the Music Do the Talking
songs.title_with_featured: Let the Music Do the Talking

description.plain: For their first song as a reunited band, Aerosmith decided to record Joe Perry’s “Let the Music Do the Talking” which he had previously released under his self-titled solo project. Everybody in Aerosmith were quite impressed with Joe Perry’s original, and thought that it would perfectly encapsulate the sound of the band as a reunited force. It became by far the most played live song from Done with Mirrors.

songs.full_title: No Surprize by Aerosmith
songs.title: No Surprize

description.plain: Steven Tyler had been having trouble during the sessions for Night In The Ruts, trying to write the lyrics for the album. He worked on this song for two months until he finally got the idea to tell the story of how Aerosmith got their big break at a club in New York City. He was so excited by this breakthrough, he has since called this song his favorite.

songs.full_title: Mia by Aerosmith
songs.title: Mia

description.plain:
Mia was one of the last songs Steven Tyler wrote for Night in the Ruts and the only one he wrote entirely by himself. On the Walk This Way memoir from 1997 he reflects on the song: “It was a lullaby I wrote on the piano for my daughter, but the tolling bell notes at the end of the song and the end of the album sounded more like the death knell of Aerosmith for people who knew what was going on.”

By the time this song was recorded Joe Perry had already left the band and those tolling bell notes were the last heard from Aerosmith for three years.

description.plain: Though it was written by Diane Warren, the woman who penned “I Don’t Want to Miss a Thing” which was Aeromsith’s biggest hit ever, Aerosmith chose not to release “We All Fall Down” as a single. It is noteworthy for being the only song on Music From Another Dimension that none of the five members of Aerosmith had a hand in writing.

songs.full_title: Walk On Down by Aerosmith
songs.title: Walk On Down

description.plain: This Bluesy Rocker was the first Aerosmith sung by Joe Perry since “Bright Light Fright” from Draw the Line, a 16-year gap. Its message, straight from the pen of Perry himself, is to pick yourself up and keep going when things are looking bad because nobody is going to help you but yourself, an autobiographical message from experience from a man who famously struggled with drug abuse.

description.plain: This cover of The Doors' famous original features a more driving backbeat (and naturally a more animated delivery from singer Steven Tyler) than the original. It was recorded for a Doors celebration album called Stoned Immaculate: The Music of The Doors after the passing of Jim Morrison, and it also appeared on the movie soundtrack for 1990’s Air America.

songs.full_title: Legendary Child by Aerosmith
songs.title: Legendary Child

description.plain: The song served as the lead single from the band’s 2012 album Music from Another Dimension! and was their first single since Devil’s Got a New Disguise in 2006. The lyrics serve as a retrospective of the band’s career. The song was originally written and recorded during the sessions for the band’s 1993 album Get a Grip, but was later reworked and released on Music from Another Dimension! 19 years later.

songs.full_title: Baby, Please Don't Go by Aerosmith
songs.title: Baby, Please Don’t Go

description.plain:
Cover of the traditional blues standard, which has its beginnings in the early 19th century and was first recorded by Big Joe Williams in 1935.

John Lee Hooker’s 1949 arrangement of the song was the basis for a number of later versions, including the famous rendition recorded by Them.

songs.full_title: Bone to Bone (Coney Island White Fish Boy) by Aerosmith
songs.title: Bone to Bone (Coney Island White Fish Boy)
songs.title_with_featured: Bone to Bone (Coney Island White Fish Boy)

description.plain: The B-Side to “Remember (Walking in the Sand),” “Bone to Bone (Coney Island White Fish Boy)” became Aerosmith’s most played song from this album with well over 100 live performances throughout the ‘80s, outpacing even “No Surprize,” which Steven Tyler has claimed is his favorite Aerosmith song. The song’s title gets its name from “Coney Island White Fish” which is a rather extended nickname for a used condom.
